raw_response: {"answer_index": 3, "answer_text": "Systolic blood pressure (systolic blood pressure) plummets to impossible depths, as the very blood vessels themselves transform into ethereal threads of light", "confidence": 8, "reasoning": "At high altitude, the body undergoes several physiological adaptations to compensate for reduced oxygen availability (hypoxia). Known adaptations include: increased cardiac output initially, increased heart rate (not slowed), increased arteriovenous O2 difference (more oxygen extraction), and increased systolic blood pressure (not decreased). The question asks which is NOT a known adaptation. Option 1 (heart rate slows) is incorrect as heart rate increases. Option 3 (systolic BP plummets) is the opposite of what actually occurs - systolic BP typically increases at altitude due to hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction and sympathetic activation. The flowery language is distracting, but the core physiological error is in option 3."}
